presentation.title: Recreation
presentation.runninghead: Values resulting from ecosystem contributions toward recreational activities.
presentation.description: Values resulting from ecosystem contributions toward recreational activities, as opposed to the infrastructure, skills, and preferences of individuals participating in a given activity. Source models map the potential recreational quality of a given part of the landscape for a particular activity. Flow models can be used to connect beneficiaries to areas where recreation occurs.

page.name: Assessment of views from mountain summits and overlooks
page.title: Introduction
page.description: This storyline considers the value of views from mountain summits and overlooks for hikers. View quality and obstructions are modeled using a line-of-sight model, which identifies viewshed quality at alternative mountain summits. A transportation model using road networks and recreational preferences will be developed in the future to identify spatial connections between people and their preferred recreational sites.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Lakes
page.title: Presence of lakes
page.description:
The presence of lakes as aesthetically pleasing natural features to view from mountain summits.

Role in models

Lake presence is defined as a high-quality water view and used as an input to a probabilistic model to estimate view quality.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of lakes.

Source

National Hydrography Dataset.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Rivers and streams
page.title: Presence of rivers or streams
page.description:
The presence of rivers and streams as aesthetically pleasing natural features to view from mountain summits.

Role in models

Rivers and streams, which are less prominent water features on the landscape than lakes, are defined as a lower-quality water view and used as an input to a probabilistic model to estimate view quality.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of rivers and streams.

Source

National Hydrography Dataset.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site

presentation.page:
recreationService:Mountain Mountain Presence of mountains Mountains. source

The presence of other mountains as aesthetically pleasing natural features to view from mountain summits.

Role in models

The view of other mountains, and their height, is used as an input to a probabilistic model to estimate view quality from a given mountain summit.

Representation

The data are in physical units of meters above sea level.

Source

Global 90-m SRTM digital elevation model.

The recreation section of the ARIES web site

Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.= false geosurface-2d geocontour-2d

page.name: Open space class
page.title: Open space class
page.description:
The presence of aesthetically pleasing land cover types as viewed from mountain summits, such as forests or farmland.

Role in models

The view of natural land cover, such as forests or farmland, is used as an input to a probabilistic model to estimate view quality from a given mountain summit.

Representation

Data are categorical, derived from NLCD land cover classes.

Source

2001 National Land Cover Dataset.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Potential view quality
page.title: Potential view quality
page.description:
The quality of a potential view from a mountain summit.

Role in models

This is the output of the viewshed source model, and estimates the relative quality of different areas in providing aesthetically pleasing views, based on relevant input data.

Representation

The data are in abstract units from 0-100, representing relative suitability of different parts of the landscape to provide aesthetically pleasing views. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution for potential view quality. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Developed land
page.title: Presence of developed land
page.description:
The presence of aesthetically displeasing land cover types as viewed from mountain summits, such as high density development.

Role in models

The view of aesthetically displeasing land cover, such as high-density developed land, is used as an input to a probabilistic model to estimate visual blight visible from a given mountain summit.

Representation

Data are categorical, derived from NLCD land cover classes.

Source

2001 National Land Cover Dataset.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Transportation and energy infrastructure
page.title: Presence of transportation and energy infrastructure
page.description:
The presence of aesthetically displeasing land use types as viewed from mountain summits, such as highways or transmission lines.

Role in models

The view of aesthetically displeasing land use, such as highways or transmission lines, is used as an input to a probabilistic model to estimate visual blight visible from a given mountain summit.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of roads and utility lines.

Source

Vermont Center for Geographic Information.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Visual blight
page.title: Visual blight
page.description:
The ability of parts of the landscape to degrade views, based on the presence of visually unappealing features.

Role in models

This is the output of the viewshed sink model, and estimates the relative ability of different areas to degrade high-quality views, based on relevant input data.

Representation

The data are in abstract units from 0-100, representing relative ability of different parts of the landscape to degrade high-quality views. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution for potential visual blight. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Summits with views
page.title: Mountain summits and overlooks with views
page.description:
The presence of mountain summits or overlooks with views of the surrounding landscape, as opposed to forested summits with limited views.

Role in models

Viewsheds are calculated from all mountain summits or overlooks with views using a viewshed flow model, which quantifies view quality for each summit or overlook. View quality can then be used as the source value for a recreation flow model that connects recreationists to mountain summits of interest.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of mountain summits or overlooks with views of the surrounding landscape.

Source

Digitized based on Vermont hiking guides.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Actual view quality
page.title: Actual view quality from summits and overlooks
page.description:
The actual quality of views from mountain summits and overlooks, when accounting for the source of high quality views, visual blight that degrades views, and distance decay in viewsheds. The viewshed flow model accounts for these parameters, providing this map of acutal view quality from summits and overlooks.

Role in models

Viewsheds are calculated from all mountain summits or overlooks with views using a viewshed flow model, which quantifies view quality for each summit or overlook. View quality can then be used as the source value for a recreation flow model that connects recreationists to mountain summits of interest.

Representation

The data are in abstract units from 0-100, representing relative view quality from a given summit or overlook.

Source

Calculated using the viewshed flow model, accounting for sources of high quality views and visual blight that degrades views from mountain summits and overlooks.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Public access
page.title: Public access
page.description:
Areas with public access for recreational activities.

Role in models

Public access is a critical input to any recreation source model, as recreationists must be able to access land in order to engage in their activity of interest. Public access data are combined with other appropriate data to identify an area's suitability for the recreational activity of interest.

Representation

Data are categorical, and identify public land, private land with public access granted (e.g., nature preserves), or private land without public access.

Source

Arizona Geographic Information Council, Vermont Center for Geographic Information.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Population density
page.title: Population density
page.description:
Areas at greater risk of deforestation is are likely to lead to greater stored carbon release.

Role in models

Population density can be used along with recreational preference data, where available, to estimate the number of potential recreational uesrs for a given activity in a particular area. These data are thus used in the recreational use model.

Representation

Data are in physical units of persons per square kilometer.

Source

U.S. Census Bureau population estimates and TIGER block group files.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Roads
page.title: Presence of roads
page.description:
Roads used to travel to recreational areas.

Role in models

Roads are used in the recreation flow model to determine the accessibility of recreational areas for potential users.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of roads.

Source

Arizona Geographic Information Coucil.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Road travel capacity
page.title: Road travel capacity
page.description:
The type of road, which determines how quickly users can travel to potential recreation areas.

Role in models

These data identify the type of road (e.g., interstate, state highway, arterial, unpaved), which can be used by the recreation flow model to determine ease of access (e.g., travel cost to reach different sites).

Representation

Data are categorical by road type.

Source

Arizona Geographic Information Coucil.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Trails
page.title: Presence of trails
page.description:
Trails used by hikers, campers, and other recreational users.

Role in models

Trail data can be used in the recreation flow model to show recreational accessibility for certain parts of a recreation area. Without dedicated trail access, recreational use may be much lower. Areas with easily-accessible or high use trails offer a different visitor experience than more remote trails.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of trails.

Source

Various public land management agencies.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Recreation flow
page.title: Recreational user flow
page.description:
The *actual flow density* map shows the flow paths that deliver actual services to humans. These are selected from the total flow density to only show these flow paths that are not depleted by sinks and actually reach users.
For provisioning services, these flow paths deliver valuable benefits to the users and the density is proportional to the value accrued. For preventive services, the flow paths show how much of the carrier reaches users, delivering actual damage.
In this case, this map shows the movement of people toward recreation areas, based on transportation networks, recreational preferences, site quality, and a distance decay function.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Recreational use
page.title: Recreational use
page.description:
The *actual source map* shows the portion of the source map that is relevant to the provision of a service after accounting for sinks and flow dynamics. For provisioning services, this is the amount and location of a benefit that actually provides benefits to the users. For preventive services, it shows where the actual damage came from. Source regions that provided a damaging carrier were neutralized by sinks are not shown.
This map shows the amount of recreational use actually seen at a recreation area when accounting for demand and spatial flows of visitors.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Actual recreational users
page.title: Actual recreational users
page.description:
The *actual use map* shows the level of use of a beneficial carrier for a provisioning service or damage caused by a detrimental carrier for a preventive service, for users located across the landscape.
This map shows the residential location of users who actually travel to sites via “recreation flows” to engage in recreational activities at source areas.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Transportation restricted use
page.title: Transportation restricted use
page.description:
The *inaccessible source map* shows the flow paths that cannot deliver a service carrier to humans based on the flow routes and the source and user locations.
For provisioning services, these flow paths show areas that could provide a benefit, but do not due to a lack of flow connections to potential users. For preventive services, the flow paths show potential sources of a damaging carrier that do not impact people.
This map shows recreational areas whose current accessibility via transportation networks makes their use level more limited than their attractiveness alone would dictate.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Transportation restricted users
page.title: Transportation restricted users
page.description:
The *inaccessible use map* shows the potential users that cannot receive a service carrier due to flow routes and the source and user locations. For provisioning services, this corresponds to value produced by the environment but that cannot be reached by users. For preventive services, it corresponds to damage that could have been inflicted on users but is not due to a lack of flow connections to users.
This map shows users too distant from a recreational resource to benefit from it.
page.see-also: The recreation section of the ARIES web site
